exploits.description: Arithmetic on u64/u128 in a financial context (amount, balance, fee, reward) without `checked_*` or `saturating_*` methods. Solana's BPF runtime uses release-mode compilation where integer arithmetic wraps silently on overflow. An attacker can supply values near `u64::MAX` to wrap balances, create tokens from nothing, or underflow withdrawal amounts.
exploits.attack_scenario: Attacker calls the instruction with `amount = u64::MAX - current_balance + 1`. The addition wraps to a small number, but the internal accounting records a massive deposit. The attacker then withdraws the inflated balance. Cost: one transaction (~5000 lamports). The program cannot detect this because Rust's release builds don't panic on overflow.
exploits.secure_fix: Replace `a + b` with `a.checked_add(b).ok_or(ErrorCode::MathOverflow)?`. For Anchor programs, also add `overflow-checks = true` under `[profile.release]` in Cargo.toml as a safety net.
exploits.prevention: All arithmetic on financial values (amounts, balances, fees, rewards, token supplies) must use `checked_*` methods. Set `overflow-checks = true` in release profile. Use `require!(amount > 0 && amount <= balance, ErrorCode::InvalidAmount)` for input validation.
confidence_reasoning: AST multi-path verification confirmed pattern

exploits.description: Raw AccountInfo 'authority' in instruction 'log_message' is not validated against any expected program owner. An attacker can pass an account from an arbitrary program, gaining full control over instruction logic. This is the #1 root cause of Solana exploits (see: Wormhole $320M, Cashio $48M).
exploits.attack_scenario: Sec3 (Soteria) AST-level static analysis detected Missing Owner Check in instruction 'log_message' at insecure/src/lib.rs:16. This vulnerability was identified through deep source code analysis using syn AST parsing. Raw AccountInfo 'authority' in instruction 'log_message' is not validated against any expected program owner. An attacker can pass an account from an arbitrary program, gaining full control over instruction logic. This is the #1 root cause of Solana exploits (see: Wormhole $320M, Cashio $48M).
exploits.secure_fix:
Replace raw `AccountInfo` with a typed Anchor wrapper:
• `Account<'info, MyState>` — automatic owner + deserialization check
• `Program<'info, System>` — for known programs
• Or add `#[account(owner = <program>::ID)]` constraint to 'authority'.
